questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

The patient's laboratory findings show high urine osmolality and low serum osmolality, which are indicative of a condition where the kidneys are concentrating urine despite low blood osmolality. This is characteristic of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion.

 

In SIADH, excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia (low serum sodium), and the production of concentrated urine (high urine osmolality). The body retains water, which dilutes the blood sodium levels but the kidneys continue to excrete sodium, resulting in a low serum osmolality.

 

Differential diagnosis - Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome (CSWS):

 

  • Fluid Status: Patients are hypovolemic, meaning there is a reduced volume of circulating fluid in the body.
  • Characteristics: It involves the loss of sodium from the body, which exceeds the loss of water, leading to hyponatremia and decreased blood volume. This condition is often associated with neurological disorders such as injuries or diseases affecting the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to high sodium levels in the blood, which would typically be associated with high serum osmolality. This does not fit the patient's laboratory findings.

 

Option C. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is an elevated level of potassium in the blood and does not correlate with the osmolality findings presented.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia is a low potassium level in the blood and, while it can be associated with various conditions, it is not directly indicated by the osmolality findings described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality, SIADH is a likely diagnosis, and the primary electrolyte abnormality to expect is hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is associated with sexual maturation defect and hypogonadism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zn (Zinc)

 

Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a critical role in numerous biological functions, including growth, immune function, and reproduction. Zinc deficiency is associated with several clinical manifestations, among which hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation are prominent. Hypogonadism refers to a condition where the body does not produce enough sex hormones, which can lead to delayed puberty, underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics, and infertility.

 

The deficiency of zinc impairs the normal functioning of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to decreased production of testosterone in males and estrogen in females. This hormonal imbalance is directly linked to the symptoms of sexual maturation defects observed in zinc-deficient individuals.

 

Zinc also plays a significant role in wound healing, immune function, and DNA synthesis. Its deficiency can lead to delayed wound healing, impaired immune response, and chronic diarrhea, further exacerbating the clinical picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium deficiency is primarily associated with oxidative stress-related conditions, such as Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy). It is not typically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Option C. Cu (Copper): Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, and neurological issues but is not linked with hypogonadism or delayed sexual maturation. Copper is involved in iron metabolism and the functioning of several enzymes but does not directly impact the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron deficiency is well-known for causing anemia, particularly microcytic hypochromic anemia, and can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and weakness. While severe iron deficiency can impact overall growth and development, it is not specifically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is directly linked to hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation, along with other symptoms such as impaired wound healing, decreased immunity, and chronic diarrhea. Recognizing and correcting zinc deficiency is crucial for preventing these clinical outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text: The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary microadenoma

 

Cushing's disease is specifically caused by a pituitary adenoma that secretes excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). This excess ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce more cortisol, leading to the symptoms of Cushing's syndrome. In the context of Cushing's disease, the term always refers to a pituitary origin.

 

Cushing's syndrome, on the other hand, can have various causes:

 

  • Exogenous Cushing's syndrome: Due to external sources of cortisol, such as prolonged use of glucocorticoid medications.
  • Endogenous Cushing's syndrome: subdivided into – 
    • ACTH-dependent - High ACTH levels stimulate cortisol production, associated with symptoms like hyperpigmentation. (e.g. pituitary adenoma/ cushing’s disease, ectopic ACTH secretion)
    • ACTH-independent - Low or normal ACTH levels, with cortisol overproduction directly from the adrenal glands (e.g., adrenal adenoma, adrenal carcinoma).

 

Among the endogenous causes, pituitary adenomas (Cushing's disease) are the most common, responsible for about 60-65% of cases. Ectopic ACTH secretion accounts for about 20-25% of cases, and adrenal tumors are responsible for 5-10% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small-cell lung cancer: Can cause ectopic ACTH syndrome but is not the most common cause of Cushing's disease.

 

Option B. Adrenal tumor: Can cause Cushing's syndrome but is less common compared to pituitary adenomas.

 

Option C. Ectopic ACTH syndrome: Can be caused by various tumors, including small-cell lung cancer, but is not as common as pituitary adenomas in causing Cushing's disease. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pituitary microadenoma is the most common cause of Cushing's disease, which is characterized by excess ACTH production from the pituitary gland.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: This fungus is known for producing yeast cells with a round, encapsulated appearance and does not exhibit broad-based budding. Instead, it forms a distinctive capsule around the yeast cells which is crucial for its identification.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option D.Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: Which of the following binds to tyrosine kinase receptors?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin

 

Option B. Insulin: Insulin binds to tyrosine kinase receptors known as insulin receptors (IR). When insulin binds to these receptors, it activates the tyrosine kinase activity of the receptor, resulting in the autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues and the initiation of intracellular signaling cascades. Therefore, insulin binds to tyrosine kinase receptors.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. LH binds to its specific G-protein-coupled receptor (LH receptor) on the surface of target cells, leading to the activation of intracellular signaling pathways via G proteins.

 

Option C. TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone): TSH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. TSH binds to the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR), which belongs to the family of G-protein-coupled receptors. Activation of TSHR leads to intracellular signaling through G proteins, not tyrosine kinase activation.

 

Option D. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): TRH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. It acts on its specific G-protein-coupled receptor (TRH receptor) to initiate signaling pathways through G proteins, similar to TSH.

 

Educational objective:

 

The insulin and IGF-I receptors have intrinsic ligand-activated tyrosine kinase activity. By binding to these receptors, these hormones will activate tyrosine kinases inside the cell which in turn phosphorylates important enzymes for involved in a number of processes such as metabolism, growth and differentiation and also inflammatory response.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed./pg – 508

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive muscle weakness, particularly affecting the eyes and throat, leading to difficulty with swallowing and drooping eyelids. Imaging studies reveal a mediastinal mass. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive muscle weakness, especially involving the eyes and throat, suggest myasthenia gravis, a condition commonly associated with thymoma. Thymomas are the most common type of anterior mediastinal mass and are frequently linked with autoimmune conditions like myasthenia gravis. In this case, the imaging reveals a mediastinal mass, which strongly indicates thymoma given the clinical context. Thymomas typically present as homogeneous, hypodense masses on imaging, though they lack specific features. Additionally, thymomas can be associated with other conditions such as pure red cell aplasia and Goode's syndrome (hypogammaglobulinemia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PTH adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are not associated with myasthenia gravis or mediastinal masses. They usually present with hypercalcemia-related symptoms and are not linked to muscle weakness or drooping eyelids.

 

Option C. Teratoma: Teratomas are also anterior mediastinal masses but are generally associated with more variable imaging features, including cystic or calcified components. They do not have a direct association with myasthenia gravis or the specific clinical symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: While lymphoma can present as a mediastinal mass, it usually presents with systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss. It is not specifically associated with myasthenia gravis or the described muscle weakness and drooping eyelids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis, presenting with symptoms like progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and drooping eyelids.

questions.text: A middle aged lady presented with difficulty in swallowing food and gritty sensation in the eyes. She is also having autoantibodies in her blood sample. What is the likely diagnosis in her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sjogren syndrome

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the exocrine glands. The gritty sensation in the eyes and difficulty in swallowing food (which can be due to dry mouth and esophageal involvement) are classic symptoms. The presence of autoantibodies, such as anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB, supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): While SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms and autoantibodies, dry eyes and dry mouth are less specific for SLE compared to Sjogren syndrome.

 

Option B. Systemic sclerosis: This condition involves fibrosis and hardening of the skin and internal organs, and while it can cause difficulty swallowing due to esophageal involvement, it is not primarily associated with dry eyes.

 

Option D. Mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD): MCTD is characterized by features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, and it can include autoantibodies like anti-U1 RNP. However, the specific symptoms of dry eyes and dry mouth are more indicative of Sjogren syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands, often accompanied by specific autoantibodies.

choices.text: Take mother's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion
Take Husband's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion
Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion
Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

questions.text: Under MTP Act guidelines, to terminate Meningomyelocele fetus at 21 weeks POG (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act guidelines in India, termination of pregnancy is permitted up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

This is divided into two categories: low-risk (up to 20 weeks) and high-risk (20-24 weeks).

 

In the case of a high-risk pregnancy, such as terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation, the opinion of two doctors is required.

 

Additionally, as per the MTP Act, only the mother's consent is necessary for the termination of pregnancy, and no consent is required from the spouse or husband.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take mother's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion - This option is incorrect because terminating a pregnancy between 20-24 weeks requires the opinion of two doctors, not just one.

 

Option B. Take Husband's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion - This option is incorrect because the husband's consent is not required under the MTP Act, and the opinion of two doctors is necessary for a high-risk pregnancy termination.

 

Option D. Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion - While this option correctly states the requirement of two doctors' opinions, it is incorrect because the husband's consent is not needed under the MTP Act.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Act guidelines in India, terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation requires the mother's consent and the opinion of two doctors.

choices.text: NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition
Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male presented to the emergency with sudden onset of abdominal pain radiating to the back, which is aggravated on lying down. Serum amylase and lipase levels are elevated. Which of the following should be avoided in managing the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infusion of 5% Dextrose

 

Explanation

 

The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of acute pancreatitis, a condition confirmed by elevated serum amylase and lipase levels.

 

Infusion of 5% Dextrose: This should be avoided in managing acute pancreatitis. Patients often experience hyperglycemia, and the administration of dextrose could worsen this condition. Preferred intravenous fluids for rehydration and initial resuscitation in acute pancreatitis are normal saline (NS) or Ringer's lactate (RL).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation: Keeping the patient NPO (nothing by mouth) is crucial to avoid stimulating the pancreas and exacerbating the condition.

 

Option C. Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition: This is correct. Early enteral nutrition is preferred over total parenteral nutrition as it helps maintain gut integrity and reduce the risk of infection.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis: This is also correct. For mild cases, early reintroduction of oral feeding is beneficial.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the infusion of 5% dextrose due to the risk of exacerbating hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, recently married, visits a local healthcare facility with her husband for family planning counseling. The healthcare provider advises various contraceptive options and takes some details to add to a specific register. This register helps the healthcare workers monitor and provide reproductive health services to eligible couples in the region. At which level of the healthcare system is this "Eligible Couple Register" typically maintained? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subcenter

 

A couple where the female belongs to the reproductive age group of 15-49 years is considered to be an eligible couple.

 

Eligible couple register is maintained at subcenter by health worker female/ ANM.

 

‘Eligible Couple Register’ is a basic document for organizing family planning work. It is regularly updated by ANM/ HW female with the help of ASHA, for the area falling within her jurisdiction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eligible Couple Register is maintained at subcentre, primarily by female health worker/ ANM

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

questions.text: Serology of IPV vaccine strains is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1, type 2, type 3

 

Explanation:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3. Although India switched from the trivalent Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to the bivalent OPV (containing only Type 1 and Type 3) as part of the global switch program in April 2016.

 

The IPV introduced in the national immunization schedule still contains all three poliovirus strains. It is a trivalent vaccine, containing Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3 strains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) introduced in the national immunization schedule of India contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3, making it a trivalent vaccine.

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely disease looking at the pattern of inheritance as provided in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

The pedigree in the image shows an inheritance pattern typical of X-linked recessive conditions. In this pattern, affected males inherit the disease from carrier mothers, while females are usually carriers and do not show the disease. All affected individuals are male, and carrier females are represented by circles with a dot. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome follows an X-linked recessive inheritance, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wilson’s disease: This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both males and females are equally affected, and carriers are not seen in the pattern observed here.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It would appear in every generation and affect both males and females equally, which is not the case in the presented pedigree.

 

Option D. Leber disease: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is inherited through maternal (mitochondrial) inheritance. It does not follow an X-linked recessive pattern and affects both sexes through maternal transmission only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked recessive conditions are characterized by affected males and carrier females, as males have only one X chromosome, making them susceptible if the gene is defective.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE")

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

 

Diphenoxylate is an opioid used to treat diarrhea by slowing down bowel movements. However, like other opioids, it carries a risk of abuse, especially if taken in large doses. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is mixed with diphenoxylate in subtherapeutic doses to deter misuse. When taken as prescribed, the amount of atropine is too small to cause significant effects. However, if someone tries to abuse diphenoxylate by taking a large number of tablets, the atropine will also accumulate and cause unpleasant side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision. These side effects are uncomfortable and discourage further abuse of the medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: This is incorrect because atropine is not added to decrease the adverse effects of diphenoxylate. In fact, when taken in large doses, atropine can add to the side effects rather than diminish them.

 

Option C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: While atropine also has anticholinergic properties that can reduce gastrointestinal motility, it is not added for this purpose in the combination. The primary reason for its inclusion is to prevent abuse, not to enhance the antidiarrheal effect.

 

Option D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: Although atropine can reduce spasms in the gastrointestinal tract, it is not included in this combination for its spasmolytic action. The dose of atropine used is subtherapeutic and does not significantly contribute to spasmolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is added to diphenoxylate to prevent the abuse of the opioid component by causing unpleasant side effects if the medication is taken in large doses, thereby discouraging misuse.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: The ideal number of ANC visits is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12-15

 

Antenatal care (ANC) visits are crucial for monitoring the health of both the mother and the fetus during pregnancy. Different guidelines recommend varying numbers of visits:

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts."
  • American guidelines and practical recommendations: Advise 12-15 visits, ensuring comprehensive care.

 

The ideal number of ANC visits, according to American guidelines and actual practice, is 12-15. This schedule is designed to closely monitor the pregnancy and promptly address any complications:

 

  • Monthly visits until 28 weeks of gestation.
  • Bi-weekly visits from 28 to 36 weeks.
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks until delivery.

 

This frequency allows for timely detection and management of potential issues, ensuring the best outcomes for both mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of ANC visits is 12-15, as recommended by American guidelines, to ensure comprehensive prenatal care.

questions.text: Identify the structures marked in numbers.  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-liver, 2-pancrease, 3-spleen

 

Explanation:

 

In the provided CT scan of the abdomen, three structures are marked -

 

  1. The first structure (marked as "1") is identified as the liver. This identification is based on its large size and position on the right side of the vertebral column. The liver is a prominent organ in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, adjacent to the anterior abdominal wall.
  2. The second structure (marked as "2") is the pancreas. Specifically, this is the head of the pancreas. The pancreas lies in the retroperitoneal space, with its head nestled in the curve of the duodenum and its tail extending towards the hilum of the spleen.
  3. The third structure (marked as "3") is the spleen. The spleen is located in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, near the stomach and under the left diaphragm. It is typically a crescent-shaped organ.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following is a criteria for making a diagnosis of an anaphylactic reaction?  (INICET MAY 2024)

  1. Swollen lips and urticaria
  2. Hypertension
  3. Breathing difficulty
  4. Persistent abdominal pain and vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Anaphylactic reaction is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that is classified as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction involves the rapid release of histamine and other mediators from mast cells and basophils, leading to a variety of symptoms.

 

Key Criteria for Anaphylactic Reaction:

 

1. Swollen lips and urticaria: These are common manifestations of anaphylaxis due to histamine release causing increased vascular permeability and vasodilation, leading to swelling and hives.

 

3. Breathing difficulty: The release of leukotrienes and other mediators can cause bronchospasm, leading to respiratory distress and difficulty in breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Hypertension

 

Anaphylactic reactions typically cause hypotension (low blood pressure) due to widespread vasodilation and increased capillary permeability, not hypertension.

 

4. Persistent abdominal pain and vomiting

 

While abdominal pain and vomiting can occur in anaphylaxis, they are not the most typical or defining features. Persistent symptoms are less commonly associated with anaphylaxis compared to the more acute and severe symptoms like swelling and breathing difficulty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of swollen lips and urticaria along with breathing difficulty are key criteria for diagnosing an anaphylactic reaction, while hypertension and persistent abdominal pain are not typical features.

questions.text: Identify this contraceptive: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lippe’s loop

 

Lippe’s loop is a type of non-medicated, first-generation intrauterine device (IUD). It is a plastic coiled device that was widely used in the 1950s and 1960s. It is characterized by its distinctive S-shaped loops, as seen in the image provided.

 

The Lippe's loop does not contain any medication or metal, distinguishing it from other types of IUDs like the Multiload, Mirena, and Copper T 380A, which have additional features or materials to enhance their contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiload: This option is incorrect. The Multiload IUD has serrated edges and typically includes copper wiring on the stem to enhance contraceptive effectiveness.

 

 

Option C. Mirena: This is incorrect. Mirena is a hormonal IUD that releases levonorgestrel and appears white in color. It does not have the coiled shape seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Copper T 380A: This option is incorrect. The Copper T 380A IUD has copper wires on the branches and the main stem, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lippe’s loop is a non-medicated, coiled plastic IUD from the first generation of intrauterine devices.

questions.text: While performing epidural anaesthesia which of these layers is not punctured ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachnoid mater

 

Explanation:

 

For epidural anesthesia, the needle is inserted through several layers before reaching the epidural space, which is just outside the dura mater. The arachnoid mater is a delicate membrane that encloses the cerebrospinal fluid and runs just under the dura mater. In epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured, as this would mean the needle has gone too deep, entering the subarachnoid (intrathecal) space.

 

Layers pierced for Epidural anesthesia (from outside to inside):

 

  1. Skin, subcutaneous tissue
  2. Supraspinous ligament
  3. Interspinous ligament
  4. Ligamentum flavum
  5. Epidural space

 

  • Structures pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture (outside to inside): Skin, subcutaneous fat, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, duramater, arachnoid mater.
  • Last structure to be pierced during epidural anesthesia : Ligamentum flavum
  • Last structure to be pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture: Arachnoid mater

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligamentum Flavum: This is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is the last ligamentous layer that the needle passes through before entering the epidural space.

 

Option C. Supraspinous Ligament: This is a strong, fibrous cord that connects the tips of the spinous processes from the seventh cervical vertebra to the sacrum. This ligament is pierced as the needle progresses towards the epidural space.

 

Option D. Interspinous Ligament: This ligament lies immediately below the supraspinous ligament and connects the adjoining spinous processes to each other. The needle also traverses this ligament as it moves toward the epidural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The arachnoid mater is not punctured during epidural anesthesia; penetration of this layer indicates a breach into the subarachnoid space, which is not the target for an epidural block.

questions.text: Which of these is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradycardia

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate (tachycardia) and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Signs of Cocaine intoxication:

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Myocardial ischemia: Cocaine can induce myocardial ischemia due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties on coronary arteries.

 

Option C. Hyperthermia: Hyperthermia is a common symptom of cocaine intoxication due to increased metabolic activity and muscle activity.

 

Option D. Agitation: Agitation is a well-known effect of cocaine's stimulant properties on the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine poisoning typically causes increased heart rate (tachycardia) rather than bradycardia, along with other symptoms like myocardial ischemia, hyperthermia, and agitation.

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH (Growth Hormone)

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is known to increase during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. During stress, the body requires more energy, which can be facilitated by the metabolic effects of GH. Similarly, during starvation or hypoglycemia, GH levels rise to help mobilize fat stores and increase blood glucose levels.

 

Deep sleep, particularly the NREM stage 3 (previously referred to as stages 3 and 4), is a crucial time for the release of GH. This hormone plays a significant role in growth, cell repair, and metabolism, which are all essential processes that occur during deep sleep.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACTH: ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) is released in response to stress but not significantly during starvation or deep sleep. Its primary function is to stimulate the production of cortisol from the adrenal glands.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Cortisol is another hormone released in response to stress and can be elevated during periods of starvation. However, it does not increase during deep sleep, making it an incorrect answer for this question.

 

Option D. Prolactin: Prolactin is not associated with increases during stress or starvation. In fact, stress can decrease prolactin levels, particularly in nursing mothers. Prolactin levels do not significantly increase during deep sleep either.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep, especially during the NREM stage 3 of sleep.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Supraphysiological doses of Vitamin B3, also known as Niacin, have been known to cause adverse effects, including macular edema and macular cysts. This side effect is relatively rare but has been documented in some cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to various eye problems, but it is not associated with macular edema and macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is essential for various bodily functions, including bone health, but it is not known to cause macular edema or macular cysts.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage, but it is not associated with macular edema or macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage (Raised AST and ALT levels, Fulminant hepatitis)

 

Niacin causes a reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy that occurs in approximately 0.67% of patients taking high doses of the drug.

 

Other symptoms –

 

  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics)
  • Hyperuricemia

choices.text: MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 8 months
MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 8 months
MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months
MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

questions.text: What is the schedule and route of administration of MR vaccine: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

 

Option C : MR Sc and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months:

 

Explanation

 

This option is correct as per the National Immunization Schedule. The MR vaccine is given subcutaneously at 9 completed months along with the first dose of Vitamin A, aligning with the guidelines for both treatments.

 

Vitamin A Supplementation schedule

 

 

In total – 9 doses – 17 Lacs IU

 

Measles vaccine schedule

 

 

Educational objective :

 

The MR vaccine should be administered subcutaneously at 9 completed months, and the first dose of Vitamin A should be given concurrently. This regimen helps to ensure optimal immune response and nutritional support, which is crucial for preventing measles, rubella, and vitamin A deficiency-related health issues.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

 

A patient with strong ego and high motivation: Advanced psychoanalysis are advised due to the patient's capacity for deep psychological work. Supportive psychotherapy, which focuses on immediate coping, is considered less effective for this patient.

 

Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at supporting the patient through reassurance, guidance, and a therapeutic relationship without delving deeply into their past or cognitive processes. It is particularly useful for patients in acute crisis, those with cognitive deficits, and severely ill patients with deficient ego functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who is in acute crisis: Supportive psychotherapy is highly appropriate as it focuses on providing immediate support and reassurance without exploring complex underlying issues.

 

Option B. A patient with cognitive deficits: These patients may struggle to understand more intricate forms of psychotherapy, making supportive psychotherapy a suitable option to provide essential support and stabilization.

 

Option C. A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning: These patients often have low frustration tolerance and cannot handle the complexities of other forms of therapy, making supportive psychotherapy beneficial to provide stability and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supportive psychotherapy is not preferred for patients with a strong ego and high motivation, as they can handle and benefit from more complex and deeper forms of therapy.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Obstructive jaundice

 

The laboratory findings indicate elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels while other liver enzymes are normal. This pattern is most consistent with obstructive jaundice.

 

In this condition, there is an obstruction in the bile ducts that prevents bile from being excreted into the intestine, leading to an accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in conditions that involve cholestasis (impaired bile flow), which is characteristic of obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: This type of jaundice is caused by the excessive breakdown of red blood cells, leading to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin. Alkaline phosphatase levels remain normal in hemolytic jaundice.

 

Option C. Hepatic jaundice: Hepatic jaundice occurs due to liver cell damage, which impairs the liver's ability to process and excrete bilirubin. This condition typically shows elevated transaminases (ALT, AST), not just alkaline phosphatase.

 

Option D. Prehepatic jaundice: This term is often used interchangeably with hemolytic jaundice, where the problem lies before the bilirubin reaches the liver. Elevated unconjugated bilirubin and normal alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in prehepatic jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase with normal other liver enzymes, obstructive jaundice should be considered as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

choices.text: Increased Amino acids
Raised glucose

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus comes with dizziness. Which of the following would be seen in a patient with hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:  

 

Hyperinsulinemia refers to an elevated level of insulin in the blood.

 

Insulin is a lipogenic hormone, meaning it promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and their storage as triglycerides in adipose tissue. This is due to insulin's ability to activate enzymes involved in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper-ketonemia: Incorrect. Insulin suppresses ketone production, so hyperinsulinemia would prevent the formation of ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Increased Amino acids: Incorrect. Insulin promotes protein synthesis and reduces the level of amino acids in the blood by enhancing their uptake into cells and their incorporation into proteins.

 

Option C. Raised glucose: Incorrect. Hyperinsulinemia lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperinsulinemia promotes increased fatty acid synthesis due to insulin's role as a lipogenic hormone, which enhances the storage of energy in the form of fat.

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants is?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors 

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • These drugs act by binding to the acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction without activating them.
  • This competitive inhibition prevents acetylcholine from binding to its receptors, thereby inhibiting the action of acetylcholine and leading to muscle paralysis.
  • This prevents the muscle from contracting, resulting in muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistently depolarizing at neuromuscular junction: This describes depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, which bind to and open the acetylcholine receptors on the muscle endplate. This causes a prolonged depolarization and prevents the muscle from repolarizing, thereby causing paralysis.

 

Option C. Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate: This does not describe the mechanism of any muscle relaxant. Persistent or repetitive stimulation would cause sustained depolarization leading to muscle paralysis, but this is not how the curare group works.

 

Option D. Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane: Some drugs inhibit calcium channels, preventing the release of neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine. However, this is not the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants work by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 779

questions.text: A patient presents with a pansystolic murmur and features of carditis. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most common manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF), which often presents with carditis as one of the major manifestations. In ARF, the most common manifestation is arthritis, which is typically a migratory polyarthritis affecting large joints such as the knees, ankles, elbows, and wrists. This arthritis responds well to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chorea: This is also a manifestation of ARF but is less common than arthritis.

 

Option C. Erythema marginatum: This is a characteristic rash seen in ARF but is less common than arthritis.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous nodules: These are also seen in ARF but are much less common than arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute rheumatic fever, arthritis is the most common manifestation, typically presenting as migratory polyarthritis that responds well to NSAIDs.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B6

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

The sideroblastic anemia comprise a group of disorders of diverse etiology in which the nucleated erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, show characteristic ‘ringed sideroblasts.’

 

SIDEROCYTES are red cells containing granules of non-haem iron. These granules stain ositively with Prussian blue reaction as well as stain with Romanowsky dyes where they are referred to as Pappenheimer bodies.

 

SIDEROBLASTS are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue reaction. Depending upon the number, size and distribution of siderotic granules, sideroblasts may be normal or abnormal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Important for DNA synthesis and prevention of megaloblastic anemia but not directly involved in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1: Known as thiamine, involved in carbohydrate metabolism, but does not play a role in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron supplementation would not help and could worsen sideroblastic anemia, as the issue lies in the utilization of iron, not in its deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia as it is a cofactor in the heme synthesis pathway and can correct the underlying metabolic defect in certain cases.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture.

 

Layers pierced while performing lumbar puncture/spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid space) from outside to inside are:

 

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

 

Upon piercing the arachnoid mater, you enter the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern), where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected during a lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is pierced before the dura mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option B. Dura mater: The dura mater is a tough outer meningeal layer that is pierced before the arachnoid mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. Pia mater: The pia mater is the innermost meningeal layer that directly covers the spinal cord. It is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.

questions.text: What is the management of choice for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coiling

 

The management of choice for aneurysms by interventional radiologists is coiling. This minimally invasive procedure involves the insertion of platinum coils into the aneurysm through an endovascular route. The coils promote clotting within the aneurysm, effectively reducing the risk of rupture and stabilizing the aneurysm.

 

Coiling is performed under the guidance of digital subtraction angiography (DSA), which allows the radiologist to visualize the blood vessels and accurately place the coils within the aneurysm. This technique has become the gold standard for treating cerebral aneurysms due to its minimally invasive nature and high success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clipping: This is a surgical procedure where a neurosurgeon places a clip at the neck of the aneurysm to prevent blood flow into it. While effective, it is more invasive than coiling and typically not performed by interventional radiologists.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). It is not a treatment for aneurysms but a supportive therapy to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Angioplasty: Angioplasty is used to widen narrowed or obstructed blood vessels, often in cases of peripheral arterial disease. It is not a primary treatment for aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coiling is the preferred management for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists, involving the insertion of coils to promote clotting and stabilize the aneurysm.

questions.text: The patient, aged 60, shows a lesion as depicted in the image below. Additionally, he reports that he felt a spider crawling in the area of the lesion when he woke up. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this information? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes zoster infection

 

The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome along with spider crawling sensation (paraesthesia) is highly suggestive of Herpes zoster infection.

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Irritant contact dermatitis

 

It typically presents with erythema and scaling and can include blistering, but it is not usually unilateral or confined to a dermatomal pattern as seen in the image.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis

 

This causes an itchy, red rash and may lead to blisters. The distribution is typically at the site of contact with the allergen and not dermatomal.

 

Option D. Herpes Simplex infection: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with a unilateral vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution, the most likely diagnosis is herpes zoster infection.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
